awd_titl_txt: A Simplified Theory of Urban Congestion
awd_abstract_narration:
This award explores the premise that traffic congestion levels on large cities may be well described with a theory that requires only three aggregate network parameters: average red and green times for traffic lights and average block size. This conjecture has been validated by the research team for a single city where data are available; verifying it with additional empirical data is therefore one of the main motivations for the proposed research. If successful, this research will have profound implications in our discipline and for the society at large. Current planning models might produce suboptimal results, because they rely on detailed origin-destination tables that may be impossible to estimate reliably, and traffic dynamics that must be simplified such that they do not adequately capture the characteristics of congestion. The proposed theory overcomes these deficiencies by employing a macroscopic approach whose results are consistent with microscopic traffic dynamics. The proposed theory enables large-scale field implementations of congestion-saving control strategies for big metropolitan areas. These strategies are robust, and independent of both origin-destination tables and of the details of the road network. This project will enhance the educational and research infrastructure by making available large amounts of empirical data and software tools for their analysis and for simulation. 

This project will seek to validate and expand the hypothesis that the Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram of an urban network, which gives average travel time as a function of average density, depends mainly on the proposed three parameters. To test this hypothesis, the research will employ empirical data from different cities around the world. The analytical framework from prior NSF-funded research will be expanded to understand the conditions where this theory is applicable. This will shed light on the effects in macroscopic network performance of traffic signal control, route choice models and congestion pricing.  Stochastic processes techniques will be employed to generate bounds to approximate network capacity reductions due to short blocks, which has proved difficult in the past. The project will develop the concept of macroscopic dynamic traffic assignment by formulating the assignment problem and its solution through a partition of the network into a collection of subnetworks, each described by a Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram. Closed form solutions will be sought for simple configurations, which will be the building blocks to develop numerical algorithms to tackle general networks. This will allow the computation of congestion control strategies, traffic state estimation and forecast over large urban networks and in real-time, all of which is intractable with current methods.

por.por_cntn:
This award seeks to develop a simplified understanding of the urban network traffic dynamics implementing the network Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram (MFD), which relates the average throughput of the network to the average density of the vehicles inside the network given that the traffic is homogeneously distributed over the network. However, the MFD cannot be defined on large-scale urban networks due to their heterogeneous nature. In this project, we demonstrated that by partitioning the network into small zones (reservoirs) with homogeneous traffic conditions, the traffic dynamics inside each zone can be described by its MFD. Therefore, for each zone, a single entity can represent all the links inside the zone leading to a significantly simplified representation of the large-scale networks. Implementing this simplified representation will help reduce the computational burden in network modeling, planning and control of large-scale networks, which can be cumbersome and even intractable in some cases.

Intellectual Merit:

The simplified multi-reservoir network representation studied in this research project enabled us to investigate the traffic dynamics inside large-scale urban networks and advance the state of the art in various ways. The main results can be summarized as below:

  1. A consistent formulation of multi-reservoir models. Our formulation of reservoir mortals ensures that they are consistent with continuum-space models  as the size of the reservoirs tends to zero. In continuum-space models the dense urban network is presented by a continuous two-dimensional space, and where vehicles can circulate at any point and the traffic dynamics at each point is given by a local speed-density relationship. By showing that the local speed-density relationship at each point should be the MFD of the vicinity of the point, we developed a multi-reservoir model consistent with the continuum space theory stating the premise: a well-defined multi-reservoir model can be interpreted as the numerical solution of a continuum model; i.e., when the size of zones tends to zero while keeping the total area constant, the discrete model tends to the continuum model. 
  2. The multi-reservoir model provides a more efficient alternative to link-level dynamic routing models. The high computational burden of traditional link-level dynamic traffic assignment (DTA) models becomes prohibitive in large-scale urban network applications since the interactions from thousands of links must be taken into account. Multi-reservoir DTA models developed in this project for both User Equilibrium and System Optimum objectives demonstrate a significant reduction in computational costs compared to the traditional link-level models and show a promising future for their application for real-time vehicle routing in large-scale urban networks. 
  3. Perimeter control methods can be easily integrated with the multi-reservoir model. The multi-reservoir model provides a ready platform for preventing Central Business Districts (CBD) from being oversaturated using the perimeter control methods. Knowing the traffic conditions inside the CBD zone, the practitioners can set the signal parameters at the boundaries of the CBD to maximize the throughput and reduce the congestion and its costs. 
  4. The network MFD can be analytically estimated using only two parameters. A previous NSF award (#1301057) by the PI has shown that the corridor MFD can be estimated by two parameters: (i) mean block length to critical block length ratio and (ii) mean signal red to green time ratio. In this project, it has been verified that the same analytical method can be used to provide an upper bound for the network MFD by computing the parameters over the whole network using the empirical network-wide data collected from more than a dozen cities.  
  5. The MFD is robust with respect to signal control. The simulation studies conducted in this project show that the MFD of large signalized networks tends to be insensitive to traffic signal control. We unveiled a large family of networks where a random control, i.e. flipping a coin to decide which phase gets the green, is comparable to optimal control. It can be concluded that on these common types of networks, resource allocation should favor policies towards reducing blocking the box rather than on sophisticated signal control algorithms.

Broader Impacts:

This project has advanced the knowledge and practice in modeling the traffic dynamics inside complicated large-scale urban networks. The results and outcomes can be implemented by researchers and practitioners to solve large-scale network planning, modeling and assignment problems. The collected data and developed codes have been made available to the public to be used and reproduced in the future research studies. The results have been shared with public audience in several conference presentation and journal publications and they have been further incorporated into the undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the PI.
